p:
The next step is to provide analogous phase diagrams for secondary infected (*-i), susceptible (*-ii), primary vaccinated (*-iii), and secondary vaccinated (*-iv) individuals against a S-4 according to variable infection rates (a-*)
β = 0.2
, (b-*)
β = 0.4 ,
and (c-*)
β = 0.8
(see Fig. 7 ). In doing so, the assumption of a low-cost vaccine is made for both costs
(
C p
=
C s
= 0.1 )
introduced above, in a case where both vaccinations are equally emphasized by the public health authority. It is worth noting that the dotted triangles for the weaker infection rate (
β = 0.2
) display higher susceptibility but lower secondary infection, despite relatively lower coverage for both vaccinations. Referring to existing studies ( Tanimoto, 2015, Tanimoto, 2019, Kabir et al., 2019a), this indicates that ‘free-riding’ on the so-called ‘herd immunity’ does occur, as a high efficiency for both vaccinations and relatively weaker infection rate only requires limited vaccination coverage within a society in order to stop the disease from spreading. This allows for a reasonable percentage of free-riders (no vaccination) to be present in the society.
